instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
threads.message: The CPU area was hit by liquid on this board. Not terrible though. I've gone through it and checked everything and replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. No CPU voltage. It's at .040V. No short on vcore. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> has <SIGNAL>HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> coming in. <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is also present on the board. Not sure what I should be looking for next to get CPU power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
threads.message: Diode mode on <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL>? Could be corrosion somewhere, any damage around <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>? <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
threads.message: Diode on <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> is pretty normal at .270. The only damage that I can see is right in the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area. <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> is present. The board is seemingly in a perfect S0 state, with all the normal voltages minus vcore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
threads.message:
The CPU requests vcore from the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> prior to <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> sending vcore via [I]<SIGNAL>CPU_VIDSOUT</SIGNAL>. [/I]If the CPU area were ht with corrosion there are two likelihoods.

1) CPU has corrosion under it.
2) CPU is dead.

I would give it an ultrasonic at something very high like 80-85 celsius for a short time period like 30 seconds to get rid of any hard gunk that may be remaining. I would also check <RESISTOR>R7280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7279</RESISTOR>, the pullups on the data lines where <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is told what to create for the CPU.

After that, I would toss in the towel. This is obviously assuming pins 16/17 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> are receiving the voltage they are supposed to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Has S0 state but no CPU
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present? Corrosion around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is always a bitch as the CPU may already be dead. Vcore not shorted?
